												When I first saw this game, I thought it would be a lot of fun: massive battles, chopping up minions, being a big damn nordic hero. I wasn't entirely wrong, but I wasn't right either. Viking: Battle for Asgard is a 3rd person hack and slash action adventure game. You play as Skarin, a Viking warrior blessed by Freya, tasked with saving Midgard (yet it's called battle for Asgard..). It takes place on 3 different islands of various sizes. It contains zero notable RPG elements, no loot, no stats, and no detailed information at all. You buy skills (moves) before really knowing much about it, you buy upgrades but don't really know how it differs from the previous one, besides it's better. It is straight forward and fairly linear. Occasionally you have multiple tasks that can be completed in any order, but they all must be completed before progressing to the next area so there really is no choice involved. There are also some strange stealth sections that just feel thrown in. Maybe they were trying to break up the hack and slash monotony, which is successful, but because it varies so much from the rest of the gameplay, you really never feel equipped correctly to do them. Those sections feel very out of place, especially when they also have a collecting bit thrown in to them (for a few achievements only) but are never explained whatsoever as to why you would be collecting the things in the first place unless you read the achievements ahead of time. You may stumble across one of the skulls, but would never know what the heck you had collected unless you read the achievements. Just seems poorly implemented.Aside from those skulls, there really aren't any secrets to be found. I like to thoroughly explore areas looking for hidden objects or areas, but there are none to be found. You may occassionally come across a random sack of gold or chest (which only contain gold or a quest item), but that's about it. Because of this, there doesn't feel like much of a reason to explore (even when you're on a rather linear path).Visuals: Because this is a console port from Xbox 360/PS3, its graphics are similar to that generation of game. As with a lot of ports, the game is very poorly optimized for PC. It lags pretty noticibly in large battles, it has no Field of View slider, very few graphics options, and the FPS is locked at 30. There is a guide on Steam that will help get the game looking better, but it still cannot unlock the FPS but will change the FOV. Before changing it, there were times when moving the camera made my eyes hurt but even then, turning the camera seemed to blur the screen in a nauseating manner. All that said, I enjoyed the visuals. There were times when things looked really impressive, scenery looked gorgeous, and combat felt visceral. I think the Creative Assembly did a great job crafting a believable world. It felt consistant and nothing really felt out of place. Small details like fences looked like they really tried to make it fit and appear to belong there. Area layouts made sense. One of the worst things to me were the animations. Some were just straight strange (dragon summoning looks like your character just collapses and goes ragdoll) and others were just lazy. Every time you fight a Giant, the 3 different Quick Time Events are animated exactly the same, every single time. The first time you see it, you think, wow, that's pretty cool; But after seeing the same thing 9 times, it gets boring and you're just waiting for it to end. Even the dismemberment kills start to get boring after a while as there only appears to be 5 or so different variations.I think had they actually put in effort on optimization and unlocking the FPS; This game would have been recieved much better on PC.Controls: I played it with a wireless Xbox 360 controller and it felt pretty good. I did not try it with keyboard/mouse at all so I cannot say how those were, but right when you load up the game, it specifically says it was designed for a controller. The controls are rather simple to understand and build slowly in complexity. The combat does get rather repetative as you end up using the same few moves as you progress. As mentioned above, the game  has Quick Time Events when fighting tough enemies. They're not particulary hard the first time you do them, and then shift into mind numbingly easy as you progress because the pattern does not change. There's only one kill animation for giants, so there's only one pattern to use every time you kill one. It's repetative and lacks any excitement.As mentioned above the camera was a problem. It seemed to have a habit of working against you any chance it got, allowing for a sword to your backside. Targeting was also rather strange and likes to work against you. Targeting in Viking seems to rely on auto locking on the target nearest to you, that's fine except when you're getting attacked from multiple sides and are trying to attack a specific enemy before they stike you, only to lunge at a different enemy and get hit multiple times in the back. What makes it worse is that even though you are swinging a sword and axe, you can only seem to hit one target at a time (unless using a special attack). Sure, your swing may go through multiple enemies (especially when they're clipping inside one another) but the same will only register a hit on one, which one can be hard to determine ahead of time.All said, I still recommend the game but not at full price. If it's under $5 and you like action adventure, hack and slash, or vikings, it's worth it. It's fun enough, the achievements are quite achieveable, and has a run time of 15-20 hours. There are worse ways to spend a weekend. 6/10

For Asgard!!!Viking: Battle for Asgard is the second  third person hack and slash, adventure game developed by Creative Assembly (following Spartan: Total warrior). You play as Skarin a nord warrier chosen by the Godess Freiar to defeat the Godess Hel and her forces who threaten to destroy Midgard.The Good+ Massive battles- There battle sequences where hundreds of troops clash.+ Unique viking mythology - From the towns, units, monsters, environement you get a nordish feeling through ou the game.+ 3 big maps to explore - Maps have are big and will take time to explore the settlements, dungeons, caves etc.+ New moves to learn - You can learn new moves through purchasing them at certain sites. These moves have certain strengths and weakness such as breaking through enemy defences, stuns or destroying shields.+ Extra collectables - You can find hidden skulls in each map which earns you an achievement.+ Quick travel shrines - You can warp between shrines by locating them.+ Magical powers - You can purchase and upgrade three spells (ice,electricity, fire) which buffs you weapon and nearby allies as well.+ Blood and gore - Combat is bloody as you hack limbs off foes.The Bad- Clunky keyboard and mouse controls due to poor port- Moveing around the place feels unecessarily cumbersome.- Lag - Faced lag spikes even after lowering graphics. Since game is old,  lag is caused by poor optimisation for pc.- Combat is not fun - The problem is that you can't counter enemy attacks, so your forced to constantly block and wait, which becomes troublesome when you are surrounded. Enemies also run faster than you so you hyave to constant block or fight them.- No sprint- With a massive map to explore, moving around can take a long time even with quick travel. - Poor map - Navigateing your map is done via keyboard controls, not mouse. It is also difficult to select an area on the map as you need to shift between regions via keyboard.- 30 FPS cap - There is no way to remove this and makes animations appear slow.- Limited weapons - You are stuck with sword, axe, throwing axes (unlock bombs later on) through out the entire game. - Poorly implemented stealth - The stealth sections feel tacked on and don't fit in the game at all.- Quick time events - Occurs during combat sewquences and gets cumbersome after a while.- Limited healing items - You can only carry 3 healing potions at a time and they don't heal you by much either. The problem comes prevailent in combat when you are in desperate need of healing.- Limited stores - Each map has only one settlement where you can buy and upgrade items. This forces you to travel back and forth over and over again to re-supply which is time consuming.- Poor voice acting - You won't care for the characters at all.- Uninteresting story - Plot is mediocre with no real plot twist, except at the end, but even that wasn't good.- Executeing unnecessary - After damaging a foe enough, you can execute them by pressing the 'E' key. The problem though is that there is no point as the enemy will bleed out if left alone and don't attack you. Although most of time executing this ability will render you invincible for a short time, some enemies may by pass this.- Limited enemies - You will face swordsman, shield guys, giants, archers, shaman, axe wielders and assassins. It sounds like alot, but as you play you will see the same enemies again and again. Final verdictOverall this game was mediocre, with the weakness hampering alot of the game play. If you are planning to pick this up I highly recommend playing on easy, just so that combat is less cumbersome as health pick ups are more common.

												Decent game, horrible port.Viking: Battle for Asgard has a potential concept: a conflict between the Viking and the Legion Army. You a.k.a the chosen warrior will build up the Viking army and lead them into the war. This game has all essential factors for a great mini sandbox hack-n-slash game: combat feels good, although it gets a little bit repetitive after 3 hours, gore effect are sick, impressive large scale battles, great characters' design and some lite RPG elements. However, it has some shortcomings such as lack of enemies' variety, boring boss battles and running from a camp to another site feels tedious (you can fast travel at some locations called Lairstone or Laystone or what-ever-the-hell-it-is), also navigating the map is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ I would have given this game a 6.8/10....butLet me remind you the origin of this game:Viking: Battle for Asgard was released on PS3 and Xbox 360 in 2008......and PC version got released in 2012. What do we have ? Enhanced graphics and kb/m support.Keyboard and mouse work great. Graphic is somewhat mediocre but it didn't bother me at all.But there's one funny thing is that the dev - Hardlight Studio made effort in enhancing graphics but they didn't UNLOCK FRAMERATE.This game is hard locked at 30FPS, there's no way to unlock it. I'm personally fine with 30FPS, but the problem is framerate drops very often, which makes combat less accurate. Once framerate drops below 20, the game runs in slow motion, YES FULL SLOW MOTION, and this happens randomly. For example, I was talking to an innkeeper, after 2 seconds, framerate drops to 15 for no good reason at all. In large scale battles with a large numbers of soldiers on screen, my laptop still can keep the framerate at 30, but when I get into a cave, which has less objects to render, framerate drops and the game goes into slow motion for 5 or 6 seconds. I don't understand what happened, why did the dev made efforts in making kb/m compatible and enhancing graphics, but managed to ♥♥♥♥ up the framerate ? I just don't get it.Viking: Battle for Asgard is a decent game ruined by technical problems. I had a good time chopping dudes' heads off and I'd say this game's well worth $4, but this horrible port is one of a hundread reasons why PC gamers are boycotting SEGA (Rome 2: Total War I'm looking at you). Hardlight, next time please don't ♥♥♥♥ up another game.

												BUY IT IF ITS ON SALE-8/10No game is perfect. Some have iffy controls, others have lame stories, and a few just have weak enemies, but even with these natural foibles, glitches and hang-ups, a videogame can transcend its limitations and be heralded as a title where the sum is greater than the parts.That isn't the case with Viking: Battle for Asgard.Set in the time when the Norse Gods ruled and people hid gold in glowing urns for some inexplicable reason, Viking, the latest from SEGA and Creative Assembly, tosses you into the massive boots of Skarin, a shirtless warrior who packs a sword and battleaxe. The game opens with Skarin mortally wounded and about to take a one-way trip to Valhalla, but Freya -- Odin's daughter -- steps in to save the Schwarzenegger-like brute as long as he pledges allegiance to her and promises to go after Hel, queen of the Underworld. Skarin agrees, gets this glowing amulet from Freya, and we're off!Now, taking on the queen of the damned isn't a one-man gig. The problem is, Hel's Legion -- an army of blue-skinned, undead bad guys -- is roaming the countryside and has imprisoned the very Vikings who would be willing to fight alongside Skarin. This means that the majority of your time in Viking is spent scouring the mountain tops and grassy plains looking for men who are usually locked in giant ribcage prisons or tethered to skull poles. Find the camps, kill the Legion, and free the men. From there, the troops usually give you some task to complete such as gathering a healing honey or eliminating a traitor, and once the odd job is complete, they join your team.See, you're freeing all of these soldiers for the massive battles that Viking revolves around. When you tap Select and bring up your map, you'll find it covered with various icons indicating enemy encampments, friendly bases and more. Of the enemy kind, you'll see some that have conditions -- free X number of troops, find the battle horn, etc. -- that must be met before you can complete the task. Usually, these are the massive battles that act as a middle and end to the level.Once you meet the battle conditions, you can select the icon on the map and jump straight into the war. Here's where all of the troops you've saved march into battle with you. If you haven't seen these skirmishes in action, they can be pretty impressive. Each one starts with a cutscene depicting a sea of your men marching toward a sea of enemies. Dragons fly overhead, Shaman are casting ominous spells in the distance, and giants wait at the ready. When the scene ends, you're thrust into the battle the imagery just set up. You and hundreds of your men move towards hundreds of enemies.Although there's no way to control what your men are doing, they're generally pretty good about following you and helping the best they can -- that is by beating the living hell out of all the blue-skinned freaks that get in their way. While your boys on the ground tend to the Legion horde, you're pretty much on your own as far as ending the battle. Each scenario has win conditions such as eliminating two of the three Shamans or taking care of a few giants. Product received for free
												Looking at the quite bad ratings this game has received, one thing should be made clear:  at its core, Viking: Battle for Asgard isn't a bad game.I do understand the reason behind the mostly negative reviews however, the game had a lot of unused potential and does seem like a rushed product. It's a shame, because the graphics are nice, the islands (where the game takes place) are fairly big and the mythological Viking setting seems good enough.So what's wrong with the game then? First of all the environment (as beautiful as it is) feels empty: no wildlife, no random events. The landscape with high cliffs, ghost ships near the shore and small groves looks exciting, but it quickly degrades into emptiness as we progress. Still the game is worth to take a look and even a playthrough.The story seems interesting enough at the beginning: Freya, the Viking goddess of love and war (in this case it's the latter) seeks out and blesses a dying warrior, Skarin, to make him her champion and lead the Viking forces against the Legion, the undead army (they look like orcs from the Lord of the Rings) of the queen of the underworld, Hel, who threatens to destroy Asgard (and Midgard). There's a twist at the end, but it doesn't really add much to the game. The story is told via cutscenes consisting of red-orange-black-white colored still images.Practically, the game is a mixture of third person hack and slash with slight adventure and even slighter strategy elements. You have to free captured Viking warriors and liberate settlements on 3 groups of islands (3 levels basically). After doing all the missions on each island, a large scale battle takes place where you must lead the Viking army against the forces of Hel. These battles look pretty impressive and amazing (there are hundreds of warriors on screen) but the poor controls (console port) take its toll: they can quicky turn into a chaotic mess, if you don't focus on the main targets. Here you have to kill shamans who summon the undead warriors and despite the urging of your fellow brethren, you have plenty of time to do so. You can utilize the help of dragons who can kill these shamans with a single breath of fire, but in order to do that, you'll need to kill shamans to recharge the dragon amulet... so you kill a shaman (or 2) in the conventional way, then you can kill the next one automatically. The shamans are invulnerable first, only after destroying their staves/totems can they be killed. At the end of the game you must face Hel herself, but surprisingly this battle is a piece of cake (what leads up to that point however isn't).As I said before the missions are quite similar: find barrels of mead, liberate encampments. The scenery however makes the exploring interesting, you can get to abandoned mines, to the top of windmills, ghost towns and caves. Sometimes you'll have to be sneaky (you can kill oppontents with a single blow from behind) and there is an achievement for finding red skulls, which really doesn't add anything apart from earning the achievement itself.There's currency (gold) in the game, with which you can buy new battle combinations, magic (ice, fire, lightning, in that order if we look at their usefulness), health extensions (permanent upgrade), health potions, throwing axes (for taking out enemies from afar), fire bombs (against multiple enemies, but they are very weak) and treasure maps (useless, you're going to find most of them - if not all - anyway). The combos are the most important things to buy, without them, you have no chance to kill more than a single opponent in combat. These can be bought at stone circles from Viking ghosts, so I suggest to look for these from the very beginning of the game. Combos can be used after collecting rage points (you can acquire 5 maximum). The use of magic isn't as good as it sounds, basically you can imbue your axe with the appropriate element (ice is the best since it freezes then shatters the enemy instantly). You can slowly recharge your magic by killing enemies and collecting the red orbs they leave behind. Unfortunately death has no consequences at all (aside from the enemies respawning in the given area, which happens anyway if you leave and haven't cleared it out completely), so while health potions can be useful, their use isn't mandatory.The controls are going to be the cause of many deaths, since Skarin can only fight one opponent at a time and seems to be 'locked' onto that single target, while most of the time the player must fight 3+ (sometimes a dozen or even more) enemies simultaneously. You can block and even dodge, but apparently these moves have been designed for duels, so by dodging you can accidentaly jump into the claws of another enemy... when facing 3 or more enemies the use of magic is heavily advised (fortunately you can use it even if it's not filled up completely).While Skarin runs extra slowly, there are plenty of portal stones that can speed up your travels (it's still going to take plenty of time). The enemies come in 5-6 different versions, some of them using shields, bows or dual-axes, but you don't really need more in a Viking themed hack and slash game. There are also ogres (killing them requires to perform successfully in QTE - quick time events - pressing buttons with correct timing) and champions. Killing these enemies is pretty easy, but again, most of the time you'll have to fight others as well simultaneously.Visually the game is beautiful (at least the landscape), the view distance is great and there are many castle ruins, cliffs and windmills from which you can admire the wonderful scenery. The music is fitting, but nothing spectacular and the sound effects feel weak and poor.The game is definitely worth checking out, it's not even remotely as bad as the user reviews would suggest. Sure it's not a deliberately good game, there are too many things missing from it, but it doesn't do anything that bad either. If you are looking for a hack and slash game between two more serious titles go ahead and give it a try.As most of you probably know, this game was part of a free bundle from SEGA, so I wrote this review as if it was a free game.PROS+ nice scenery, interesting locations+ Viking settingCONS- lack of content- bad, console based controls- missions has no real rewards- dying has basically no consequenceRATING5/10

												This game got mediocre reviews at best, but the video still caught my attention and I decided to give it a try. I was pretty pleasantly surprised.To start, this is not a deep game. There are next to no RPG elements. Think of it as a GoW type game. The animations are a little clunky and a controller is crucial. It is definitely a console port. Many people also complained about it being grindy. There are only 3 islands, and completing them really is much the same. However, I didn't mind because I enjoyed the gameplay.That being said, this was a great game to come home to and just mindlessly kill. For much of the game, you're running solo and taking on small groups of enemies with your typical combat. Explore areas and delve into caves. Free guard towers and small forts. It's all typical stuff. However, the game shines in the variety of battles.To take back control of an important area, you must clear that area of enemies. Sometimes this is easier said than done. Luckily, there is usually a prison full of captured comrades nearby. Just sneak in and free them and they help in the fight! This type of battle changes the game into a small melee.Then you have ambushes. On certain areas of the map, the bad guys have patrols running around. These things are big (20-30+ troops( so you aren't going to be attacking them solo. Get enough allies and prepare an ambush. These battles are slightly bigger than he melees but fast paced and action packed.You can also do stealth missions in an enemy occupied city. Again, you run around solo, but you're in the middle of the enemy control zone. This means anything less than perfect stealth will result in death. You sneak by most opponents but occasionally stop to assassinate a guard or five.Finally is the big daddy... the city seiges. They come in various sizes and complexities, but each of them needs you to persuade an entire army to join you. And believe me... you take an army. This part of the game almost reminds me of DotA. Enemies constantly respawn from their Shamen and you have to influence the outcome of the battle by taking on the Shamen as well as other important commanders and troops. You also bring dragons with you after you unlock them (3 in all). They fly around and pretend to fight until you give them commands. Basically you just tell them a target to kill (strategic targets or the mini bosses mentioned above). Using the dragons doesn't get too detailed, but it adds great atmosphere to the battles. These things are chaotic!All in all, it isn't going to win Game of the Year or anything, but I had a ton of fun. It was one of the few games that I played right through without getting bored.

												Viking: Battle for Asgard is, at first glance, an inoffensively mediocre hack and slasher that's a bit like God of War if it was set in Magic Scandinavia and featured a mute meat freezer disguised as a man instead of a screaming psychotic ballerina dancer. And for the most part, it's exactly that. Slower, heavier combat, magic limited to spicing up your sword blows, and all the platforming and puzzles replaced with incredibly basic stealth mechanics.The game is so utterly devoid of original thought that it's hard to give it a proper review. While this isn't in and of itself worthy of a negative recommendation, this incredibly formulaic game falls apart on the eve of the giant battles that end each level. Before you can summon your ever growing army and your small collection of dragons and just drop them on the enemy's head, you always are made to sneak through your enemy's base to accomplish one task or the other, while snatching up the stores of gold they have scattered 'round.Its these parts where the game screeches to a halt, because the method of enforcing stealth basically consists of placing ten times the normal density of enemies in an area and telling you to sneak around assassinating exactly the right ones, because if even one of them spots you, you have about six seconds before every enemy within a hundred feet dogpiles you, and unlike say Assassin's Creed, the enemies here have zero concept of Mook Chivalry, and will happily stunlock you to death, dumping you back at your base to start the entire process over from scratch.I've personally made it a little over halfway through the game, but after repeating the exact same scenario about three dozen times, the game's sluggish combat loses its charm and I can't say I care how the game ends anymore. Probably predictably, given the flow of every other aspect of the story.

												My first Creative Assembly product was Spartan: Total Warrior back on the PlayStation 2. Despite all the mediocre press attention, I personally believe it was a remarkable title and an extremely good contender against well established franchises such as God of War or even games of similar scale such as Dynasty Warriors. Viking on the other hand doesn't quite live up to the same standards, but isn't all that bad once you get into grips with how the gameplay works and familiarise yourself with the core mechanics. Your main objective is to pretty much assembe an army big enough to reclaim the lands. More or less Lord of the Rings, but with vikings. You need to complete favours for individual clans/groups in order to gain their trust and expertise. All in all there's three islands to conquer with the first island serving more as a tutorial and introduction to how everything works. At the beginning controls may feel a bit tedious but that's something you'll get used to by the time you complete the first island. Although I felt the main protagonist was uninspiring and quite simply dull, he manages to pull his own in combat once you acquire special attacks from spirits of Valhalla at arenas; and magical skills from the Blacksmith which promote magical skills - fire, ice and lightning. Major boss encounters are also on the underwhelming side as they fail to display any real challenge, although the battle leading up to the final encounter is far more challenging . There's a lot of running around between objectives which may become a drag at later stages where the landscape is remarkably bigger. Overall I was personally satisfied with the product to some extent, but wish it were similar to that of Spartan where the player could somewhat relate to a speaking protagonist in a brutal and relentless title.

												Viking: Battle for Asgard ist an Action Adventure with Hack 'n' Slash combat set in an open world in the viking age with fantasy elements. I won't say anything about the story or the characters since I was so bored by this game that I muted it and prefered to watch some videos or podcasts.I gonna start my review with the most said thing: This is a horrible port. It has everything YOU would not in a decent and optimised PC game: 30 FPS lock that results in stuttering and laggy gameplay, low FOV for a way too close camera, lack of essentail menu options like higher resolutions and clunky controlls both in combat and menu/map since its desinged for gamepad.Despite all these issues I played through the whole game, but it was very tiresome. The combat is so-so. The Hack and Slash is being freshened up by special moves, items and rune skills which either feel essential in order to kill some enemies (like the shieldbearers) and some do not seem to have any impact on your damage. One versus one battles are very easy (yes, even the final boss 1v1), while as soon as the count of enemies rises, you run into problems: When attacked you get stunned and if five enemies hit you, you either block or die, which results into very defensive combat at that point. The "stealth" part is ok, very limpsy since the FOV of your enemies is not consistent and sometimes you can eliminate a whole squad without being spotted, sometimes they spot you with their back through a wall.The good thing about the combat is the variety of the enemies, plenty of weak ones to mow down, some require a different approach, some should be focused first; then there are bigger ones which all are a bit challenging when combined with others.One thing that I hoped to be good are the big battles and oh boy, they look very impressive. Hundreds and thousand of enemies storming towards each other, clashing their weapons and you are fighting amongs your brothers-in-arms to reach the heart of the city. Sadly, your brothers are very stupid, you feel very weak since every enemy respawns and the only helpful thing you can do, is to storm alone through the enemy (since your army is just as stupid as theirs) and focus the onjective (mostly a shaman) and rushing it down. And when you are at the front, you feel alone and overwhelmed, since you are alone and 20 enemies are attacking you, leaving you to block and cry in a corner.The world is really nothing special, it has its moments but overall look boring, has very ugly textures and mapping and traversing it is even worse. Speaking of world, it has a lot for you to do, sadly it's always the same: either talk to an ally, free an ally or loot a chest after you have killed everyone near the point. The busy work lasted 10 hours for me and after half the game the repetitive work gets very dull.Speaking of repetitive, most of the interacting and some of the combat is tied to Quick Time Events. From finishing off a weakend giant and getting rid off of an assassin, over ripping open a cage to free your kin and opening a gate, to picking a lock and opening a chest, you have to smash your keys.The graphic is not the best, but acceptable.Overall, this game is way less than medicore, on the edge to horrible. Combat is repetitive, dull and boring, the busy work you get is just as repetitive and the PC port is an insult to this platform.Not worth the full price, not worth a dollar, would never play it again or tell anyone to who wants to have fun.

												Viking: Battle for Asgard is a hack and slash game with RPG elements. The hacking and slasing is very well executed and makes for a very addictive game. However, it's easy to get dissappointed in Viking if you go in with hopes for an open world RPG in the likes of Gothic or Elder Scrolls. The game is disguised as an RPG, but calling it one would be an insult on the genre. I am reluctant though to judge a game based on what it's not. Once you come to terms with what this game really is (a simple hack n' slasher), it's easier to cope with it.------Pros:------+ Open world.+ Great battle combos and killmoves.+ QTE slaying is very well done.+ Huge battles with hundreds of NPCs participating.+ Cool enemies, but I wish there were more different types of them.+ Stealthy approach supported.------Cons:------- The environment seems dull and empty. There are no amazing sights to see, no animals, nothing to gather, nowhere to climb, nothing to loot other than money, can't go into houses, many invisible walls, overall there's few to hold the lore together.- The human settlements often didn't even have living areas or had 1-2 for the whole settlement. There was no agriculture, the humans (99% were men) walked around in battle outfits, the settlements never had any distinctive elements that would make them different from each other etc.- Of course they had to add horns to viking helmets on enemies because noone knows that they first appeared in one of Wagner's musical plays in the 19th century.- Since it's a viking-themed game, you'd expect the environment to look something like Scandinavia...you know...since vikings came from there, but it looks nothing like Scandinavia, it's like the developers didn't even bother to google what their nature looked like.  - The weather effects look awful.- The protagonist looks like a big monkey in an outfit that looks asian/japanese origin.- Uninteresting story.- NPC's seem to move around aimlessly, it really stands out.- Character cannot swim.- You can't sprint and enemies move faster than you.- Outstandingly stupid AI.- God awful map/menu/minimap.- Only two difficulty levels, where Normal translates to Very Easy.--------Verdict:--------Despite all it's flaws, I enjoyed it. The things that were good, were very good. The things that were bad were connected to the game not being RPG enough. I just wish it had more lore.

												The Vikings terrorised British shores over 1200 years ago, with the first raids recorded in the early 790’s. The Vikings raided England, Scotland, Ireland and Wales and they must have loved these shores as they kept coming back for more. The most recognisable invasion was the Norman Conquest in 1066 - some of you will remember this from History at school. I could go on giving you a lesson about the Vikings, but truth be told, this is about a particular Viking - Skarin, in Viking: Battle for Asgard.For centuries war has been bloody and relentless between the Underworld and Asgard. The Underworld, led by Hel, Queen of the Underworld, has her merciless soldiers who are known as the Legion, to destroy the realm of the Gods, Asgard. The reason for this is that Hel is looking for the God-killing weapon that can break the chains of Fenrir, Wolf God and brother to Hel. Legend believes that whoever breaks these chains starts Ragnarok; Fenrir will rise into the sky and swallow both the sun and moon, and most importantly creating a new age to be ruled by the person who initialises Ragnarok.With Hel’s reasoning for her war, Freya, Goddess of Light and Asgard, calls upon you to stop the evil Hel from initialising Ragnarok and calls upon you, Skarin, to battle Hel, Drakan (Hel’s Harbringer; as what Skarin is to Freya), and the Legion of the Underworld.Viking: Battle for Asgard is a very good free-roam hack-n-slash title. Its gameplay is addictive and easy to play. Basic controls, very good combinations of attacks and dragons make Viking: Battle for Asgard worth it. It executes what it set out to achieve - fun and addictive gameplay.

												I can see a little bit of potential in Viking: Battle for Asgard. Although I felt there are a number of things wrong with this game that brought it down into the “not recommended” category. The story, from what I can gather, is that you’re a Viking brought back to fight a Legion army and eventually destroy a woman named Hel. You battle across 4 islands (You re-visit one of them so it’s really only 3 distinct locations) On each island you must raise an army large enough to take over the stronghold, find a rune to summon a dragon and upgrade your weapon. Every island has the same basic objectives and it’s very repetitive. With such vast open areas you think there would be more scenarios, but it’s the same formula 4 times in a row. The gameplay itself is average to below average. The fighting system is clunky which becomes very apparent when you are fighting multiple enemies at once. You end up having to push everyone away from you to separate them out in order to hit them. Otherwise, the surrounding enemies will hit you during your attacks, causing you to be stunned. You are forced to take on a defensive strategy. The extremely narrow FOV also handicaps you as attacks will come blindly.There is a very basic upgrade system of buying new moves and power-ups. There are not any character stats, just collecting gold to buy these things. The extra moves and combos were useful, but I found myself only using the lighting, fire and ice special attacks barely a handful of times during the game. The levels are large but mostly empty. There are a number of fast travel locations in each map, which helps but you’re still required to run around the map discovering them first. Your characters running speed is far too slow for these big distances. The graphics are acceptable and the environment can look quite good. Maybe it was just my game, but I had no in-game music except for the big battles. So most of the time I was listening to my own footsteps. The large battles seem to be the “best” part of the game, but even this is lacking. The battles are great visually. It was awesome to see my large army charging toward the enemy. Ultimately, you are forced to battle on your own to kill Shamans and giants. Thus making the large scale battle seem unnecessary as you and your enemies respawn continually. Pros+Decent graphics+Large scale battles look cool+Large maps (albeit empty)+Environment+Good set of moves to learnCons+30fps+Clunky combat system +Repetitive gameplay+QTE (quick time events) used excessively +World map lacks zoom or free movement+Narrow FOV+Character run speed too slow+Stealth sections+Voice acting+Small enemy variety This isn’t a game I’d recommend to friends. However, if you’re really into Vikings and hack and slashes, you may want to give this game a try if there is a good sale. 4/10 Below average

												MEDIOCRE!Ok, now that thats out of the way, this game isn't necessarily bad. If you have a huge backlog of great games, theres no real reason to waste time on this one. It takes elements from a lot of popular games and shoves em all into one pretty unspectacular title. The combat is like a watered down God of War. You will be able to unlock new combos and upgrade 3 basic spells, but none of them are particularly satisfying to use. Honestly, you can beat the whole game by just block-parrying all the enemies. Also the game has a wierd combat mechanic where you can press a quicktime button (expect a lot of quicktime events for all boss fights) to execute a weakened enemy. The problem with this is that if you don't execute the enemy, he will just die automatically after a few seconds. It is fun to see the gory executions, but it gets old real fast. It is also possible to stealth kill enemies if you sneak up on them behind.There are some basic platforming "puzzles" in some dungeon areas. They aren't really puzzles though. Theyre pretty straightforward things like climbing net ladders, shimmying across narrow walls, tiptoe walking over planks, and jumping across gaps.There are 3 acts to this game, each putting you on a large map where you will have to explore to complete quests. I gotta say though, the acts are VERY similar to each other. The only difference is that the maps are different. I took a break of months between each act so that it wouldn't feel so repetitive. The story is lame, as is the dialogue, music, and sound effects. The good this is that you can just skip it all. This isn't exactly a bad game, it's just very mediocre. I played it through to the end eventually because it is good to play if you just want a mindless rpg where you don't have to pay attention to anything.

												So this is Legend of Viking: A Chain-Link To The Past.If you remember Spartan: Total Warrior and Ocarina of Time, you get the idea. There are a few differences, of course, but a lot of those differences come in the form of 'axes' and 'different reasons magic is happening.' Also your magical instrument doesn't cause weird ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to happen, except perhaps the summoning of a bunch of 'vikings.'Never mind that the main character is the most viking thing about this game. I mean look at him, tattoos on his tattoos, he has a two handed sword and just because he felt he was a little light on hardware, he decided he should bring about sixy axes too. He's so metal he basically doesn't wear clothes and lets everyone else do all the talking between piles of gore. Or he would, if he wasn't dead all the time.Hilariously enough, unlike those previously mentioned games, he also suffers for not wearing armor and can't take on all the problems himself, 'cause the numerous enemies he has to deal with can wiffle bat him to death. This is assuming everything works out fine and you either A. Have a controller (hopefully xbawx) or B. Have tarantulas for hands so that you can work the♥♥♥♥♥backwards default keybindings. It's somewhere between the average VCR and Dark Souls in user friendliness. So how does the game get around this?Well, when there's more than 3-5 enemies, the game usually has you summon a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of vikings. Thanks to the well known norse power of 'friendly fire off' you can wade into similarly colored and shaped friend and enemy alike mashing the attack button and magnetically snap to the bad guys to kill them a lot. You also have magical powers that do things like set every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ around you on fire, which is a fairly significant force multiplier.Okay, enough being a♥♥♥♥♥♥about this: my biggest question about this game is just an endless series of 'why's.Like, why do I have to summon an army? Am I not cool enough to just kill everything on my own like, say, anyone in a character action game in the last 10 years? Or ♥♥♥♥, a game that is actually designed fairly similarly, Dynasty Warriors? Like, what could I possibly be contributing to a bunch of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off vikings that outnumber whomever we're going up against? Other than, say, fighting the kinds of antagonists that give those vikings trouble... So... Why am I fighting in the main battle when I can just kill those? It seems like the kind of thing that looked okay written on paper. I mean really, the battles may as well be a cinematic if there's not some big road block (which there haven't been any thus far) because I can literally just stand there and watch them fight for me. There are no commands to give, so far as I can tell, and nothing changes about the combat interface when a big battle happens, so, weirdly enough I fell kind of extraneous.Or, the F button, ohmigod the ♥♥♥♥ing F button.Okay, so what makes me need to mash it to get a door open? Or throw a switch? Or open a chest? Or open another door? Why is it that when my finger lets off the ♥♥♥♥ing button that the character goes through a failure animation that's actually longer than the success animation? Do you honestly think I need to be engagued for opening every single ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ door, that my interaction with this thing needs to be highlighted by adding to the entropy to my keyboard? 90% of games nowadays are okay with making that a single button press. And, oh yeah, this game also automates climbing up smaller ledges, so why not just automate opening♥♥♥♥♥♥too? I mean am I really going to go near something like that and not take care of it?The plot, thus far, could also have been written by people who read that 'tarantulas for hands' sentence earlier and got really excited, and really just raises a whole bunch of questions: If Freya is okay with throwing Hel's legions out of the starting 'Viking-Town' with a magical hand wave and saving us from certain death, why doesn't she just hand wave away all the other dead vikings? Or the whole Hel invasion thing? Also, we have teleporter runes that take us place to place, and I have seen other vikings using this, without me 'unlocking' them, so why on earth are invasions restricted by land at all? They don't seem to guard the oft referred to in norse myth teleporter rocks so why not just stand in our literal stone circle and get the vikings a viking on everybody's doorstep? Rather than 'battle for asgard' this game should have just had the subtitle 'Don't ♥♥♥♥ing think about it' 'cause that seems like the only way any of this makes sense. I mean, thanks for the free game Sega, but really, why?TLDR: If you like dynasty warriors, play dynasty warriors, if you like total war, play total war, trying to smash both together doesn't work super well.

												whilst there is quite a bit of detail in the blood/gore department, the gameplay itself is very very repetitive, gets boring after around 3-4 hours of doing the same thing over and over (find bad guy camp, kill everything, save warriors for big battle, repeat until final big battle, next area).the combat itself takes some time and practise to get used to since it is very outdated and stiff (evading is useless against the bigger champion bosses) but feels pretty cool once you get the hang of things - it feels good chaining attacks and decapitating like 5 guys without geting hit once.i could care less for the narrative, since most brawler style games have a paper thin narrative used ot get players from point Ato B, so i cant really comment there, besides it being very generic (save the day chosen one).visually the game is decent, with the protagonists character model reminding me of conan the barbarian (arnie from the 80's movie). the visuals reminded me of fable... must have been the glow on things that washes the colours out... i odnt know, but i guess they where both very pretty games at their time of release (both games have aged nicely as well).sound is hit or miss - the sound of a sword or battle axe crunching through an emeies spin is very satisfying, but there is little else in the sound department (aside from annoying effect noises, like walking in puddles or climbing ropes).overall i would give the game a 6.5/10 b/c whilst is had a cool concept (gathering an army for large scale battles), it became boring and repetitive very quickly. i would recommened purchasing this if it's on special (i got it for $5 so i'm not really complaining), otherwise skip it.P.S the AI in large battles is as dynamic as the AI in the dynasty warrior games, so dont expect cool and epic wars, since you will be doing most of the decapitating (if not all).

Posted: October 3, 2014
												Minimum 75% off sale - recommended.This game has a similar feel to brutal legends or gothic 3 (lite) in that for the most part one travels the map as an individual protaganist freeing locations so that every so often a grand battle can be had. With a check point system there's infinite respawn making it a very casual game but also tedious as everything is reset until an area is completed in one run through. There are aspects of rpg... collect cash to unlock new moves, increase special powers and health but its all very superficial and lite and actually gives the game a reverse difficulty curve as no new enemy are introduced after the second island. There is also an inventory of sorts - 3 consumables, 3 powers and a repeatable passive buff.The game isn't really open world but more 3 large islands with progression related restrictions in place making each island effectively 2 parts. Quests/missions are either kill everything here (primary), kill everything and bring back item(secondary), stealth for item/assination.(once per island).The Grand battles break up the flow and usually consist of several stages each with a set goal - kill 1 shamen, kill 2 shamen kill 3 shamen... etc... this can either be done directly or by killing optional targets to charge up the dragons and then watching them via cutscene fullfil the primary objectives.Although for the most part an enjoyable game if somewhat repetative this suffers from being a console port and having some particularly annoying features all of which are showcased to a high degree in the final mission/bossfight.Tight POV with overly large player character dominating the screen.Nasty camera with impeded vision from environment/sfx. The camera also has an auto-return function making it difficult to handle while getting smacked around or travelling uphill.semi-auto target lock - can get real annoying at times when the combo switches target mid sequence or doesn't lock.Gamepad orientated controls with repeat tap action for environment interaction and bossess.30fps cap - any framerate dips lead to sluggish controls (Reported - Nvidia issues).halfscreen draw distance for grass etc very noticable in snow environments.No real graphics customisation beyond low/medium/high defaults... although the game directory can be directly editted.Does what is does farily well - could have been so much better.

												Viking: Battle for Asgard is pretty cool I guess.Set during true historical events when an army of endless Viking zombies invaded Denmark, Germans: Battle for Berlin follows the blights of Skarin, a powerful warrior with amazing hair.  After being injured in battle, Skarin is visited by the three fairy god mothers. Except there's only one, her name is Freya and she tells you that Hel is super mad and is invading the world of the living.So mom tells you that you should be her champion in return that she heals your wounds and rids your besieged town from the zombie scourge. Why she doesn't just do this at any given time is beyond me, but I digress. From here, Skarin and his hair are sent out on a journey to amass an army of not-zombie Vikings to fight the zombie Vikings for total Viking supremacy. I would also like to add that Viking is a fun word to say. Your journey takes you across three islands on your quest to make Hel your girlfriend. Each of these islands has two or three major locations you and your army needs to take over. See, this is where♥♥♥♥♥♥gets real. France: Battle for Paris is made by Creative Assembly, a dev team known for their Total War games which always boasts large numbers of units on screen at once. So when♥♥♥♥♥♥gets too hot with the other gang, you bring all of your homeboys at once in what can only be described as the world's angriest mosh pit. For it's original release, you could have called Viking a sort of tech demo for later Total War games. See, your boys and Hel's boys don't just whack at each other with bats that look like swords, they actually single one another out for pretty cool looking duels. They wrestle, they clash, stab, cut, whatever to get the other guy to stop moving around so much.  But where do you come in in this whole escapade of violence? Much like my high school self, Skarin is violent and prone to kill people. He plays much like a slower, less angry Kratos. You have a strong attack, a heavy attack, a list of combos, as well as a dodge and a block/counter mechanic. Mix these together with some lame stealth segments and some pretty cool magic mechanics, and Skarin is a dangerous adversary in his quest to date the goddess of the Dead. But all this being said, should you play Spain: Battle for Madrid. It's repetitive, there's a lot of walking and just picking stuff up. But when the game gets going, ho man does it get going. The big battles are grand enough to get your blood pumping, which is good because that's the games biggest selling point.The game is a port from a console game that came out quite awhile ago, and you'll probably see a lot of technical problems from the era. Get this game on sale, if not just for the few and far between big scraps. Poland: Battle for Warsaw gets 3 smelly men from the middle ages out of 6. Rats and horses can't vomit. 												Viking: Battle for Asgard (V:BA) gets a thumbs down from me because I have already played games like it that were far more fun.  The story of V:BA involves Skarin, a viking who is granted immortality and uses it to wage a guerilla war against a demon army.  The single player is composed of three islands that follow the same formula: clear points of interest (POI) under demon control through stealth or meleee combat, free imprisoned vikings at the POI, do search-and-destroy/fetch quests to gain allies/items, summon a dragon, assualt the fortress on the island, fight the boss, and finally advance to the next island to do it all again.  You will clear the same POI's on each island and fight the same monsters during each siege all the while enjoying one of the games three musical tracks.  Sound and voice work are below average at times, bordering so-bad-its-good territory.  Combat is stiff and gets stale halfway through the game because you've fought every enemy you'll see.  You get to do some pretty epic things (large scale battles with hundreds of npcs) in this game, but the framerate cap, repetitive nature of the game, and lack of polish make me glad I got this one for free.

												I really liked this game. It's made by the same company that did the Total War series and it kind of feels similar to playing as a troop during one of their battles at times.It's very similar to some of the action genre staples like God of War, Darksiders etc but your character unlike most games is not overpowered and if you get into a fight with too many opposition troops at once then you'll quickly get destroyed. The game largely relies on you personally becoming better at utilising the combat moves as the game develops, rather than making you increasingly more powerful so that the basic moves are still just as good at the start.. I greatly prefer this method as by the end of the game you feel pretty skillful at combat because of this.. it becomes all about timed dodges and moves to destroy armor and shields, it's quite technical for an action game but at first when you don't have access to all the available moves and you're just starting out the same technical feel instead feels quite clunky but it does develop into something good.Some aspects of the game are a little bit repetative, but they're not overly tedious while being much of the same thing you just did recycled as theres a decent number of enemy types and they all require slightly different tactics to beat.Some of the large battles are genuinely quite difficult as once they start you have no direct control over any of the troops on your side and some of the objectives are much easier when you have their backing, as charging in by yourself doesn't work out so well generally but it does give the feeling of being involved in a proper conflict, though the constant voice overs of someone demanding that you go kill the enemy shaman etc is a bit annoying when you're trying to get some of your troops through enemy lines to help you out.Overall I would recommend this game. For the price it goes for when it's on sale or in bundles these days it's a steal.

Grab it on a sale, and have a 360 controller on hand since the KB&M controls are relatively terrible in my opinion. 												The liklihood is you are reading this because you either bought a Total War bundle that came with this, or are considering it.  If you are just considering buying it seperately - know this: this game is not a good one.  It drags on for 12 hours of mostly tedium, with repetative 2-button combat interspered with the same QTE's all the way through.This game is also a bad port.  Every time you launch via Steam, it will ask your permission to download distributables, then give you the option to configure its minimal pc settings (which can't be changed in-game) or launch.  That option window will be launched at least 6 times every time you play, so when you quit, you'll have to shut all the redundant ones down.The game is limited to 30 fps.As the intro blubs mentioned the game was designed for a gamepad, and the keyboard config looked terrible, i opted to play on a 360 controller.  That meant inverting the y-axis as is my custom.  This you have to do every single time you launch the game, as it does not remember game settings.The actual game involes a mute viking called Skarin, who is made immortal by Freya to fight the undead Legion of Hel's army.  The game takes place in 3 maps.  On each map you liberate small bands of viking warriors (fully armed and armoured in their cage) at various locations to bring them under your banner, track down a dragon stones to summon a dragon, then assaulting one or two fortresses to complete the map.The assaults on the fortresses allow you to use the dragon(s) you aquire to aid you, but you need dragon runes to use their one-shot kill attacks on targets.  You get runes by either defeating enemy shaman (who constantly resurect their allies - and are always the main targets of the assault), or killing enemy champions or giants by spamming your power attacks and then finishing them off with a QTE.  Your viking buddies will assist you, but you have to do all the heavy lifting.In these battles, it is very difficult to know what the hell is going on with regards to who you are attacking and who is attacking you.  This will lead to a lot of damage being taken.  If at any point you are surrounded by a large group, you can expect to die, you have no AOE attack, and the enemies will stun-lock you and wipe you out quickly.Your attacks are limited to quick and heavy, with heavy limited to being stuck on the end of a combo due to its long charge up time to use on its own.  You can learn some extra attacks for gold that do heavier damage by consuming "rage" which is generated by hitting enemies.  You can finish enemies off with a heavy attack once they lose a limb to generate more red souls, which enable you to charge your weapon and allies around you with an element (fire, lightning or ice).Thrown into the hack and slash is a stealth element, which enables you to one-shot enemies that are unaware, and gives rise to the incredibly frustrating missions to infiltrate the enemies fortress and do 'a thing' before your main assault on the fortress.  Getting spotted is easy if you don't follow the preferred route to your objective, and will lead to getting mobbed and killed, meaning restarting the entire endeavour.The game is about 4 or 5 hours too long, not helped by the slow pace of your protagonist, who lumbers around painfully slowly between his goals.  You can fast travel between waystones, but only if you are at one already, and their position isn't always ideal.It is absolutely not worth £9.99.

												Want to feel like a Viking? Play Mount & Blade. In short; badly ported, poor controls, clunky combat and a worthless story. In long;From the begining the game does a terrible job explaining how to play. Nothing tells the player which buttons do what. Experimenting with the controls before entering combat wont help, because the main character will just draw his swords and thrust them in the direction he is facing rather than demonstrate a light or heavy attack.Visually, the game is lacking. The poor optimization limits the quality of the game to the moderate preset on my computer. Animations are slow and clunky, sound assets are ear-bleedingly bad, and the texturework is just ugly.Combat feels pretty slow, lacks weight and variety at first. In the begining all the player can do is mash A for light attacks, X for heavy, and hold Lbumper do defend. It is possible to learn combos in the Arena, but they probably wont be used often, and are expensive to learn. There are also 3 types of runes and 3 items, one of which is a healing potion. I'm describing the controls for an Xbox controller, because keybard controls are rediculously hard to use. Using the keyboard, even if the default keys are rebound, will require the player to reach across to perfom different moves.The story makes no sense at all. The game opens with Freja, a norse goddess, giving an amulet to the main character and explaining that he needs to lead an army to stop Hel from invading and conquering the world, and thats it. No reason is given for why Hel is invading Midgard, or why the other gods wont interfere, or even who the main character is. Hints are given that the main character is possessed by a demon, but nothing other than that is said.
